messageBody:
To make JUnit fail whenever an error is detected, I would actually
recommend changing/extending the behavior of TestResult, which must be
plugged into the particular test runner that you're using.

// textui/MyTestRunner.java
protected TestResult createTestResult() {
return new TestResult() {
public synchronized void addFailure(Test test,
AssertionFailedError t) {
super.addFailure(test, t);
stop();
}
};
}

It seems like a lot of people shy away from making these sorts of
modifications, but I want encourage anyone who's using, or considering
using, JUnit that the code base is intentionally small and easy to
digest so that customizing it's behavior does not require a herculean
effort.

-shane

On Wednesday, March 20, 2002, at 12:18 PM, Vladimir Bossicard wrote:

>> Is there a way to have the test suite
>> abort if one of the tests fails. in other words, if the first test in
>> the
>> list fails, then the remaining tests are not executed. In my suite()
>> method
>> I list the specific tests I want to run, rather than just returning a
>> new
>> TestSuite with the testcase class specified.
>
>
> If your tests are dependant from each other, you may reconsider refactor
> them so that they can be execution in any order.
>
> As for JUnit, unless you modify the runners, I don't think you can
> parametrize JUnit to do what you want. If you use Ant, you have the
> "haltonfailure" option of the JUnit task but you have to check if it's
> really what you want.
>
> general note: if you don't specify a suite() method, JUnit will
> automatically extract all your test methods from your class. So you
> don't need to write
>
> public static Test suite() {
> return new TestSuite(myClass.class);
>
> }
>
>
>> Also, I am having trouble with the Swing UI tester. It created a
>> junit.properties file to set the "loading" property to false, but it
>> does
>> not find my property file. I specified the USER.HOME env variable as
>> well
>> as putting the file in my classpath.
>
>
> The best way to figure out where JUnit looks for junit.properties file
> is to search the file on your hard drive. JUnit searches for the
> "user.home" variable and not "USER.HOME", maybe it's the problem.
>
> -Vladimir
